ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Very slow crawling?
ygData.msgSnippet: Once the crawler is down to just one or two sites to crawl, the limiting factor is its politeness: it only requests one URL at a time, and it pauses several

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Very slow crawling?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=kaxxXY9QpAr5JAovKyxmazdgo6O06Y-HCEKlF3NFMmUE
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

Once the crawler is down to just one or two sites to crawl, the limiting
factor is its politeness: it only requests one URL at a time, and it
pauses several seconds (by default) between requests (and longer if the
request takes a long time).

So a URI rate less than one per second isn't unusual.

Also, it's typical for the last host(s) a crawler is visiting to be
those that are largest, slowest, or possibly even not responding at all
(in which case the crawler is in a slow-retry mode waiting ~15 minutes
between tries).

You can look in the crawl.log and the 'frontier report' for more info on
what the crawler it still working on, and whether it is working on a
large, slow, or unresponsive host.

The 'estimated' time remaining is a completely unreliable number: a
simple linear projection of the rate acheived so far applied to the
number of URIs remaining. It is almost certain to be a wild
underestimate, because as noted, the end of a crawl is dominated by a
few large/slow/unresponsive hosts (so previous rates aren't
representative), and crawls typically discover yet more URIs than are
currently known.

- Gordon @ IA

Tony Wang wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> I'm testing Heritrix 1.4 on my dedicated box and I have set up a job 
> that crawls the following websites:
> http://www.eBiomethods.com
> http://www.molecularstation.com
> 
> On the console panel, the progress bar shows:
> 
> *Rates*
> 0 URIs/sec (0.33 avg)
> 0 KB/sec (10 avg)
> *Time*
> 1d9h17s elapsed
> 13d20h5m27s remaining (estimated)
> 
> See that I still have almost 14 days remaining to complete the crawl. I 
> wonder if I misconfigured something in the job or it's normal?
> 
> Thanks!
> 
> Tony
